head.citation-title: Reduction of surfactant adsorption by alkali substances in carbonate reservoir
head.abstracts: Surfactant flooding is a technique performed to reduce interfacial tension between oil and water to ultra-low condition since its structure composes both hydrophilic and hydrophobic parts. Oil is then liberated in a form of emulsion and residual oil saturation can be nearly zero. Nevertheless, the process encounters problem which is surfactant loss due to adsorption onto rock surface. This problem weakens the effectiveness of the injected surfactant slug, causing the process to be uneconomical. The results show that co-injection of alkali helps reduce surfactant adsorption better than pre-injection mode. Moderately strong base which is sodium carbonate is also recommended as it provides adequate charge to adsorb onto carbonate surface and at the same time, it is not too strong to push surfactant closer to rock surface. Alkali concentration of 0.6% is observed to be optimum concentration as it tends to adsorb onto rock surface instead of surfactant throughout the range of surfactant concentration used in this study. Results from dynamic test shows that adsorption is only ten percent compared to static test while percentage of desorption is higher than static test. Differentiation between static test and dynamic test is possibly due to different surface area of grains and pores.
